title: Scientific Computing course
text:
Material properties
The problem was to find the effective Youngâ€™s modulus and Poisson coefficient of a composite material. The case was set up such that we had a block of matrix material inside which there are 5 parallel fibres that have high Youngâ€™s modulus and low Poisson coefficient. The mesh on FigureÂ 1 was generated with Gmsh.






FigureÂ 1: Meshed geometry



The simulations were performed using ElmerFEM.

title: Scientific Computing course
text:
Heatsink
The problem was to find the steady state temperature distribution of a given heatsink if the heating power was 100 W. The simulation result is on FigureÂ 2.






FigureÂ 2: Streamlines of air in steady state

title: Nerve signal modelling
Deep Learning course
text:
In this course I had to sumbit 2 course works which included experimenting with different neural network architectures, such as

convolutional,
recurrent,
graph message passing,
autoencoder,
generative adversarial networks and
physics informed networks.

All the code for running these models are in two repositories, the reports can be found in the root of the repositories. Project 1 and Project 2.

title: Catenary in Wind
Catenary in Wind
text:
Wind force
For aerodynamic drag we can use a simple equation \[
F_w = \frac 12 \rho v^2 C_d S,
\] where \(\rho\) is the air density, \(v\) wind speed, \(C_d\) drag coefficient and \(S\) the cross-sectional area. Knowing that the cable has diameter \(d=1.2\unit{mm}\) and drag coefficient of a cylinder is \(C_d = 1.17\) the equation for wind pressure is \[
f_w = \frac{C_d}{2} \rho v^2 d.
\]
